â
'''Microsoft Security Essentials''' ([[List of Microsoft codenames|codenamed]] '''Morro''') is a [[freeware|free]] [[antivirus software]] created by [[Microsoft]] that provides protection against [[Computer virus|viruses]], [[spyware]], [[rootkit]]s, and [[Trojan horse (computing)|trojans]] for [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], and [[Windows 7|7]].<ref name="Reuters" >Finkle, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/CMPTRS/idUSN1044924620090610 "Update 3-Microsoft will soon unveil free anti-virus software"], [[Thomson Reuters]], June 10, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> Originally in [[Software_release_life_cycle#Beta|beta]] testing, it was available for download to the first 75,000 people in the [[United States]], [[Israel]], [[People's Republic of China]] and [[Brazil]]. The final build was released on September 29, 2009.[http://www.pcworld.com/article/172762/microsoft_security_essentials_launches_tuesday.html]
+
'''Microsoft Security Essentials''' ([[List of Microsoft codenames|codenamed]] '''Morro''') is a [[freeware|free]] [[antivirus software]] created by [[Microsoft]] that provides protection against [[Computer virus|viruses]], [[spyware]], [[rootkit]]s, and [[Trojan horse (computing)|trojans]] for [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], and [[Windows 7|7]].<ref name="Reuters" >Finkle, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/CMPTRS/idUSN1044924620090610 "Update 3-Microsoft will soon unveil free anti-virus software"], [[Thomson Reuters]], June 10, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref>
MSE replaces [[Windows Live OneCare]] â a subscription antivirus service â and [[Windows Defender]], which only protects users from [[adware]] and [[spyware]].<ref name="SuperSite" >Thurrott, Paul. [http://www.winsupersite.com/win7/mse_beta.asp "Microsoft Security Essentials Public Beta"], Paul Thurrott's SuperSite for Windows, June 18, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> MSE is a small-footprint program ideal for computers that lack processing power or [[broadband]] [[Internet]] connections, such as [[netbook]]s.<ref name="bbc" >[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7737520.stm "Microsoft to offer free security"], BBC News, November 19, 2008, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> It is geared for home use, unlike Microsoft's upcoming enterprise-oriented product [[Microsoft Forefront]].
MSE replaces [[Windows Live OneCare]] â a subscription antivirus service â and [[Windows Defender]], which only protects users from [[adware]] and [[spyware]].<ref name="SuperSite" >Thurrott, Paul. [http://www.winsupersite.com/win7/mse_beta.asp "Microsoft Security Essentials Public Beta"], Paul Thurrott's SuperSite for Windows, June 18, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> MSE is a small-footprint program ideal for computers that lack processing power or [[broadband]] [[Internet]] connections, such as [[netbook]]s.<ref name="bbc" >[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7737520.stm "Microsoft to offer free security"], BBC News, November 19, 2008, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> It is geared for home use, unlike Microsoft's upcoming enterprise-oriented product [[Microsoft Forefront]].
Line 33: Line 33:
==Development==
==Development==
â
Microsoft announced ''Morro'' on November 18, 2008. It marked a change in Microsoft's consumer antivirus marketing strategy. Instead of offering a [[Windows Live OneCare|subscription antivirus]] with a host of other tools â [[parental controls]], [[backup|photo backup]], and a [[personal firewall|firewall]], ''Morro'' would be free for all genuine installations of Windows and simply offer protection against [[malware]].<ref name="bbc" /> [[Microsoft Forefront]] will be offered alongside ''Morro'', with central management tools not present in ''Morro''.
+
Microsoft announced ''Morro'' on November 18, 2008. It marked a change in Microsoft's consumer antivirus marketing strategy. Instead of offering a [[Windows Live OneCare|subscription antivirus]] with a host of other tools â [[parental controls]], [[backup|photo backup]], and a [[personal firewall|firewall]], ''Morro'' would be free for all genuine installations of Windows and simply offer protection against [[malware]].<ref name="bbc" /> [[Microsoft Forefront]] will be offered alongside ''Morro'', with central management tools not present in ''Morro''. Originally in [[Software_release_life_cycle#Beta|beta]] testing, it was available for download to the first 75,000 people in the [[United States]], [[Israel]], [[People's Republic of China]] and [[Brazil]]. The final build was released on September 29, 2009.[http://www.pcworld.com/article/172762/microsoft_security_essentials_launches_tuesday.html]
A leak of version 1.0.2140.0 revealed the internal name of ''Morro'' was changed to Microsoft Security Essentials.<ref>Protalinski, Emil. [http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/06/leaked-microsoft-security-essentials-codename-morro.ars "Leaked: Microsoft Security Essentials (codename Morro)"], [[Ars Technica]], June 17, 2009, accessed July 19, 2009.</ref>
A leak of version 1.0.2140.0 revealed the internal name of ''Morro'' was changed to Microsoft Security Essentials.<ref>Protalinski, Emil. [http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/06/leaked-microsoft-security-essentials-codename-morro.ars "Leaked: Microsoft Security Essentials (codename Morro)"], [[Ars Technica]], June 17, 2009, accessed July 19, 2009.</ref>
